thread.title: Notre Dame, Clemson quarterbacks take center stage in high-pressure game
thread.title_full: Notre Dame, Clemson quarterbacks take center stage in high-pressure game - The Denver Post

author: Pete Iacobelli
title: Notre Dame, Clemson quarterbacks take center stage in high-pressure game
text:
CLEMSON, S.C. — Clemson's Deshaun Watson and Notre Dame's DeShone Kizer share similar names, the leadership of two high-performing offenses — and the pressure to succeed when the sixth-ranked Fighting Irish (4-0) and 12th-ranked Tigers (3-0) collide Saturday night.
Watson and Kizer have played well so far, although neither has faced the quality defense — or the enormous hoopla — they will at Death Valley this weekend.
"There's always some sort of hype. We're Notre Dame," Kizer said. "Every game is going to be a big game in its own sense, and obviously this is the first time that I'll really be playing in front of 90,000-plus screaming fans from down South."
Watson is accustomed to those crowds, bringing a 5-0 record at Memorial Stadium into the contest. The preseason pick for Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year and considered a Heisman Trophy contender when the season began, Watson has completed nearly 75 percent of his passes this year for 641 yards and seven touchdowns.
This game won't impact Clemson's chances to win the Atlantic Coast Conference title, win or lose. Still, Watson understands the bigger picture out there with Notre Dame.
"It's kind of just another steppingstone to what we're capable of, being one of those teams in the playoff," Watson said. "Just embrace the moment and know your priorities and what you really have to focus on."
Advertisement Kizer got thrown into the lineup with the injury to Fighting Irish starter Malik Zaire, out for the year with a fractured ankle.
Kizer rallied Notre Dame to victory at Virginia on a touchdown pass to Will Fuller with only 12 seconds left. Kizer has continued his strong play since, completing 67.7 percent of his passes for 541 yards and five touchdowns this year.
Overall, Kizer is guiding a Notre Dame offense that is playing at a breakneck pace.
The Irish have scored seven touchdowns of 50 yards or longer this year, the most in a season under coach Brian Kelly. Notre Dame also has rushed for 1,139 yards. The last time the Irish had more through four games was in 1992, when they had 1,264.
Clemson coach Dabo Swinney is duly impressed by Kizer's play, calling him "an 'ice water in his veins' kind of guy."
Both quarterbacks will have an added adversary in the field conditions. The fast, clean track these two high-powered offenses expected at Memorial Stadium probably will be a slick field with several inches of rain forecast to fall on Clemson on Friday and Saturday. Hurricane Joaquin is lurking off the South Carolina coast, and the storm's uncertain track could mean an even wetter outlook. Clemson officials are consulting with the National Weather Service to monitor the storm.
Clemson officials met Friday morning and confirmed their ability to operate the game. They feel confident in the planned resources and personnel at Death Valley.
The school said in a news release that the field is in good playing condition and power to Memorial Stadium remains unaffected, despite reported outages in other campus areas.
